standard_metadata.standard_description: Construct a function to model a linear relationship between two quantities. Determine the rate of change  and initial value of the function from a description of a relationship or from two (x, y) values, including reading these from a table or from a graph. Interpret the rate of change and initial value of a linear function in terms of the situation it models, and in terms of its graph or a table of values.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Relating linear contexts to graph features

question.content: A lake near the Arctic Circle is covered by a $2$-meter-thick sheet of ice during the cold winter months. When spring arrives, the warm air gradually melts the ice, causing its thickness to decrease at a constant rate. After $3$ weeks, the sheet is only $1.25$ meters thick.  Let $y$ represent the ice sheet's thickness (in meters) after $x$ weeks.  **Which of the following information about the graph of the relationship is given?**

options.content: Slope and a point that is *not* an intercept
$y$-intercept and a point that is *not* an intercept

hints.content: To describe a point on the graph, we need a corresponding $(x,y)$ pair.  In our case, these are corresponding values of weeks since spring arrives and thickness of ice.  $\begin{align} \scriptsize\text{weeks since spring arrived}&\quad\scriptsize\text{thickness of ice} \\ \downarrow&\quad\downarrow \\ \large (x &,\quad\large y) \end{align}$  To describe the slope of the graph, we need information about the rate of change of the relationship.  In our case, this is the rate at which the thickness of ice changes over time (in meters per week).
The ice is $2$ meters thick at the start of spring, when $0$ weeks have passed. This corresponds to the point $(0,2)$ and is a $y$-intercept.
After $3$ weeks, the sheet is only $1.25$ meters thick. This corresponds to the point $(3,1.25)$ and is not an intercept.
The $y$-intercept and a point that is *not* an intercept are given.

question.content: Hiro painted his room. After $3$ hours of painting at a rate of $8$ square meters per hour, he had $28$ square meters left to paint.  Let $y$ represent the area (in square meters) left to paint after $x$ hours.  **Which of the following information about the graph of the relationship is given?**

options.content: Slope and a point that is *not* an intercept
$y$-intercept and a point that is *not* an intercept

hints.content: To describe a point on the graph, we need a corresponding $(x,y)$ pair.  In our case, these are corresponding values of hours of painting and area left to paint.  $\begin{align} \scriptsize\text{hours of painting}&\quad\scriptsize\text{area left} \\ \downarrow&\quad\downarrow \\ \large (x &,\quad\large y) \end{align}$  To describe the slope of the graph, we need information about the rate of change of the relationship.  In our case, this is the rate at which the area left to paint changes over time (in square meters per hour).
Hiro painted his room at a rate of $8$ square meters per hour. This corresponds to a slope of $-8$.
After $3$ hours of painting, Hiro had $28$ square meters left to paint. This corresponds to the point $(3, 28)$ and is not an intercept.
The slope and a point that is *not* an intercept are given.

question.content: Conrad read a $180$-page book cover to cover in a single session, at a constant rate. It took him $6$ hours.  Let $y$ represent the number of pages left to read after $t$ hours.  **Which of the following information about the graph of the relationship is given?**

options.content: Slope and a point that is *not* an intercept
$y$-intercept and a point that is *not* an intercept

hints.content: To describe a point on the graph, we need a corresponding $(x,y)$ pair.  In our case, these are corresponding values of hours of reading and number of pages left to read.  $\begin{align} \scriptsize\text{hours reading}&\quad\scriptsize\text{pages left} \\ \downarrow&\quad\downarrow \\ \large (x &,\quad\large y) \end{align}$  To describe the slope of the graph, we need information about the rate of change of the relationship.  In our case, this is the rate at which the number of pages left to read changes over time (in pages per hour).
Conrad has $180$ pages left when he has read for $0$ hours. This corresponds to the point $(0,180)$ and is a $y$-intercept.
It took Conrad $6$ hours to have $0$ pages left to read. This corresponds to the point $(6, 0)$ and is an $x$-intercept.
The $x$-intercept and $y$-intercept are given.

question.content: A charity organization had to sell $18$ tickets to their fundraiser just to cover necessary production costs. They sold each ticket for $\$45$.   Let $y$ represent the net profit (in dollars) when they have sold $x$ tickets.  **Which of the following information about the graph of the relationship is given?**

options.content: Slope and a point that is *not* an intercept
$y$-intercept and a point that is *not* an intercept

hints.content: To describe a point on the graph, we need a corresponding $(x,y)$ pair.  In our case, these are corresponding values of number of tickets sold and net profit.  $\begin{align} \scriptsize\text{tickets sold}&\quad\scriptsize\text{net profit} \\ \downarrow&\quad\downarrow \\ \large (x &,\quad\large y) \end{align}$  To describe the slope of the graph, we need information about the rate of change of the relationship.  In our case, this is the rate at which the net profit changes per ticket sold (in dollars per ticket).
The organization had to sell $18$ tickets to cover their production costs and bring their net profit from a negative value up to $\$0$. This corresponds to the point $(18,0)$ and is an $x$-intercept.
They sold each ticket for $\$45$. This corresponds to a slope of $45$.
The slope and $x$-intercept are given.

question.content: Burro Travel Bureau arranges trips for descending into the Grand Canyon. For each trip, they charge an initial fee of $\$25$ in addition to $\$0.10$ for each vertical meter they descend.  Let $y$ represent the fee (in dollars) of a trip where they descended $x$ vertical meters.  **Which of the following information about the graph of the relationship is given?**

options.content: Slope and a point that is *not* an intercept
$y$-intercept and a point that is *not* an intercept

hints.content: To describe a point on the graph, we need a corresponding $(x,y)$ pair.  In our case, these are corresponding values of numbers of vertical meters descended and total trip fee.  $\begin{align} \scriptsize\text{vertical meters}&\quad\scriptsize\text{trip fee} \\ \downarrow&\quad\downarrow \\ \large (x &,\quad\large y) \end{align}$  To describe the slope of the graph, we need information about the rate of change of the relationship.  In our case, this is the rate at which the trip fee changes with distance (in dollars per meter).
The travel bureau charges an initial fee of $\$25$, when they have descended $0$ meters. This corresponds to the point $(0,25)$ and is a $y$-intercept.
The travel bureau charges an additional $\$0.10$ for each vertical meter they descend. This corresponds to a slope of $0.1$.
The slope and $y$-intercept are given.

question.content: Apolline is mowing lawns for a summer job. For every mowing job, she charges an initial fee plus a constant fee for each hour of work. Her fee for a $5$-hour job, for instance, is $\$42$. Her fee for a $3$-hour job is $\$28$.  Let $y$ represent Apolline's fee (in dollars) for a single job that took $x$ hours for her to complete.  **Which of the following information about the graph of the relationship is given?**

options.content: Slope and a point that is *not* an intercept
$y$-intercept and a point that is *not* an intercept

hints.content: To describe a point on the graph, we need a corresponding $(x,y)$ pair.  In our case, these are corresponding values of hours of work and total fee.  $\begin{align} \scriptsize\text{hours of work}&\quad\scriptsize\text{total fee} \\ \downarrow&\quad\downarrow \\ \large (x &,\quad\large y) \end{align}$  To describe the slope of the graph, we need information about the rate of change of the relationship.  In our case, this is the rate at which the total fee changes over time (in dollars per hour).
Apolline's fee for a $5$-hour job is $\$42$.  This corresponds to the point $(5, 42)$ and is not an intercept.
Her fee for a $3$-hour job is $\$28$. This corresponds to the point $(3, 28)$ and is not an intercept.
Two points that are *not* intercepts are given.

question.content: A charity organization had a fundraiser where each ticket was sold for a fixed price. After selling $200$ tickets, they had a net *profit* of $\$12{,}000$. They had to sell a few tickets just to cover necessary production costs of $\$1{,}200$.  Let $y$ represent the net profit (in dollars) when they have sold $x$ tickets.  **Which of the following could be the graph of the relationship?**

images.alt: graph of an increasing linear function in quadrant 1 with a positive y-intercept
graph of an increasing linear function in quadrants 1 and 4 with a positive x-intercept and negative y-intercept
graph of a decreasing linear function in quadrants 1 and 4 with a positive x-intercept and positive y-intercept
graph of a decreasing linear function in quadrant 4 with a negative y-intercept

hints.content: The profit *increases* with each ticket, so we expect to have a *positive* slope.
They had to sell a few tickets just to cover production costs (to bring their profit from a negative value up to $0$), so we expect a positive $x$-intercept.
Based on this description, we expect a positive slope and a positive $x$-intercept.

images.alt: graph of an increasing linear function in quadrants 1 and 4 with a positive x-intercept and negative y-intercept

question.content: Nour drove from the Dead Sea up to Amman, and her altitude changed at a constant rate. When she began driving, her altitude was $400$ meters below sea level. When she arrived in Amman $2$ hours later, her altitude was $1000$ meters above sea level.  Let $y$ represent Nour's altitude (in meters) relative to sea level after $x$ hours.  **Which of the following could be the graph of the relationship?**

images.alt: graph of an increasing linear function in quadrant 1 with a positive y-intercept
graph of an increasing linear function in quadrants 1 and 4 with a positive x-intercept and negative y-intercept
graph of a decreasing linear function in quadrants 1 and 4 with a positive x-intercept and positive y-intercept
graph of a decreasing linear function in quadrant 4 with a negative y-intercept

hints.content: Nour's altitude *increases* after driving awhile, so we expect to have a *positive* slope.
Nour starts *below* sea level, so we expect a *negative* $y$-intercept.
Based on this description, we expect a positive slope and a negative $y$-intercept.

images.alt: graph of an increasing linear function in quadrants 1 and 4 with a positive x-intercept and negative y-intercept

question.content: Mr. Mole left his burrow that lies below the ground and started digging his way at a constant rate deeper into the ground.   Let $y$ represent Mr. Mole's altitude (in meters) relative to the ground after $x$ minutes.  **Which of the following could be the graph of the relationship?**

images.alt: graph of an increasing linear function in quadrant 1 with a positive y-intercept
graph of an increasing linear function in quadrants 1 and 4 with a positive x-intercept and negative y-intercept
graph of a decreasing linear function in quadrants 1 and 4 with a positive x-intercept and positive y-intercept
graph of a decreasing linear function in quadrant 4 with a negative y-intercept

hints.content: Mr. Mole *descends* each minute, so we expect to have a *negative* slope.
Mr. Mole starts *below* the ground, so we expect a *negative* $y$-intercept.
Based on this description, we expect a negative slope and a negative $y$-intercept.

images.alt: graph of a decreasing linear function in quadrant 4 with a negative y-intercept

question.content: Naoya read a book cover to cover in a single session, at a rate of $55$ pages per hour. After $4$ hours, he had $350$ pages left to read.  Let $y$ represent the number of pages left to read after $x$ hours.  **Which of the following could be the graph of the relationship?**

images.alt: graph of an increasing linear function in quadrant 1 with a positive y-intercept
graph of an increasing linear function in quadrant 4 with a positive x-intercept and a negative y-intercept
graph of a decreasing linear function in quadrant 1 with a positive x-intercept and a positive y-intercept
graph of a decreasing linear function in quadrant 4 with a negative y-intercept

hints.content: As Naoya reads each hour, the number of pages left *decreases*, so we expect to have a *negative* slope.
After Naoya read for a while, he still had $350$ pages left, which means he started with even more pages, so we expect a *positive* $y$-intercept.
Based on this description, we expect a negative slope and a positive $y$-intercept.

images.alt: graph of a decreasing linear function in quadrants 1 and 4 with a positive x-intercept and positive y-intercept

question.content: Kayden is a stunt driver. One time, during a gig where she escaped from a building about to explode(!), she drove at a constant speed to get to the safe zone that was $160$ meters away. After $3$ seconds of driving, she was $85$ meters away from the safe zone.  Let $y$ represent the distance (in meters) from the safe zone after $x$ seconds.  **Which of the following could be the graph of the relationship?**

images.alt: graph of an increasing linear function in quadrant 1 with a positive y-intercept
graph of an increasing linear function in quadrant 4 with a positive x-intercept and a negative y-intercept
graph of a decreasing linear function in quadrant 1 with a positive x-intercept and a positive y-intercept
graph of a decreasing linear function in quadrant 4 with a negative y-intercept

hints.content: Kayden's distance *decreases* after driving awhile, so we expect to have a *negative* slope.
Kayden starts out $160$ meters away from the safe zone, so we expect a *positive* $y$-intercept.
Based on this description, we expect a negative slope and a positive $y$-intercept.

images.alt: graph of a decreasing linear function in quadrants 1 and 4 with a positive x-intercept and positive y-intercept

question.content: A young sumo wrestler decided to go on a special high-protein diet to gain weight rapidly. When he started his diet, he weighed $79.5$ kilograms. He gained weight at a rate of $5.5$ kilograms per month.  Let $y$ represent the sumo wrestler's weight (in kilograms) after $x$ months.  **Which of the following could be the graph of the relationship?**

images.alt: graph of an increasing linear function in quadrant 1 with a positive y-intercept
graph of an increasing linear function in quadrant 4 with a positive x-intercept and a negative y-intercept
graph of a decreasing linear function in quadrant 1 with a positive x-intercept and a positive y-intercept
graph of a decreasing linear function in quadrant 4 with a negative y-intercept

hints.content: The wrestler *gained* weight each month, so we expect to have a *positive* slope.
The wrestler weighed $79.5$ kilograms when he started his diet, so we expect a *positive* $y$-intercept.
Based on this description, we expect a positive slope and a positive $y$-intercept.

images.alt: graph of an increasing linear function in quadrant 1 with a positive y-intercept
